They either collect the scrap from the large garbage bins to find plastic containers or by moving around with a tricycle, in most cases calling households through loudspeakers. While they don't have to pay for the scrap plastic, they do pay for the scrap metal. Thus, they must have money in hand to buy the scrap metal. 

The reason that they are seeking your financial help is that they have to buy scrap and also continue doing some minor work in the home seen in the photograph. 

The couple is extremely poor, yet very responsible, and they have proved it through seven other previous loans.

loans.use: to buy scrap metal and then sell it at a higher price; also, to continue doing minor repair work in their home

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more goods for the customers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy new tools for his work and tiles.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase merchandise to expand her store’s inventory

loans.name: Tausi

texts.en:
Tausi, who is in her mid 40s, is married with three children — one son and two daughters who are still at school. She has been running a retail shop for 20 years now. She works from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be her eighth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to keep increasing the shop inventory and has paid back all her loans successfully. She used the profit to pay school fees and loans repayments and covered household expenses. She is happy with the loan and appreciates Kiva for their support. She will use this loan to increase the retail shop inventory. She dreams of building a second house.

Tausi will make sure she pays back her loan according the loan schedule.

loans.use: to increase the retail shop inventory.

loans.name: Kimanga Group

texts.en:
Omari is a single man in his early 30's with no kids. He has been buying cows and selling meat. He has had his butcher shop for three years now. He works from 10 am to 9 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Omari's 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to buy cows. He sold more meat and bought a fridge for the butcher shop.

loans.use: to buy cows and sell more meat in his butcher shop.

loans.name: Nayfe

texts.en:
Nayfe is a 39-year-old Lebanese married mother of one child. In 2012, Nayfe decided to help her husband. She opened a local store which sells clothes. This is to supplement her income and live in better conditions. She has special selling methods and provides a high quality of products. She is well-known in her region with the special talents in her domain.

Today, Nayfe is demanding a loan from Kiva partner, Vitas s.a.l, to increase her business merchandise with new and special collections. This will help to meet the needs of her clients in order to increase her income. Nayfe is very proud of her business growth and she hopes to expand her earnings.

loans.use: to increase her clothing shop with new and special collections.

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en:
Hanan is a 43-year-old married woman living with her husband and five children. She has worked as a private teacher since 2008. She chooses this profession because she feels that she is helping students to get the needed education.

Hanan arranged a room in her house, equipped with the required materials and supplies, where she receives her students. Today, Hanan is applying to borrow a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to buy a new car to help her in her work. She is very optimistic about her future and wishes to receive more students with the coming school season.

loans.use: to buy a new car to help her in her work.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy wood to make yet more furniture to sell.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma is a 46-year-old married woman with three children, two of whom are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Wilma has a beauty parlor business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 17,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy new tools and beauty products for her beauty parlor. Wilma has been in this business for four years. In the future, Wilma would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy new tools and beauty products for her beauty parlor.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past one year, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of customers taking too long to repay for goods taken on credit. 

With the loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more goods.

loans.name: Bas Bibi

texts.en:
Bas Bibi is a 52 year old woman and mother of five children. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband sells fruit like apples, bananas and grapes. 

Bas Bibi's husband needs to purchase fruit to resell to improve his sales and earn maximum profit. But due to an unfavorable financial position her husband is not able to purchase fruit for his business.

Therefore Bas Bibi has applied for a Kiva loan from field partner BRAC Pakistan so her husband can purchase fruit for his business. 

Bas Bibi is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to enable her husband to purchase fruit to sell.

loans.name: Hawraa

texts.en:
Hawraa is a 24-year-old single Lebanese woman who lives with her parents. She started working in the agricultural field since three years old. She likes her occupation so much because she likes to feel her independence. She cooperates with her siblings to collect enough money to be able to pay the heavy living expenses.

Today, Hawraa is applying to borrow a youth loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. The loan will be used to purchase seeds and seedlings for plantings for her business. She is very positive about her future and wishes to ameliorate her lifestyle.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and seedlings.

loans.name: Khazne

texts.en:
Khazne is a 46 year-old married mother of four children. She has been working for the past four years from her house. She sells homemade foods such as pickles, thyme and oil to help her family financially. 

Khazne is obtaining a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l. to increase the amount of merchandise available to her clients. 

She is very sure that she will sell all her products and expand her business. Khazne hopes that in the future to open her own store to attract more customers.

loans.use: to increase the amount of merchandise available to her clients.

loans.name: Neema Kimara Group

texts.en:
Juma is in his mid-twenties and married. He has two children; one is in school while the other is yet too young to attend. He has sold fish for seven years now to earn a living. He works from 5:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Juma’s 25th loan through Tujijenge Tanzania. He used his previous loans to increase the amount of fish he sold and has paid back all of his loans successfully. He used his profits to pay school fees, buy a TV set, a radio, mattresses, beds, a sofa set and a piece of land upon which he built his house. He also repainted and tiled his place of business. He has managed to cover household expenses as well.

Juma and his loan group member call themselves "Neema Kimara." Juma is applying for a 2,800,000 TZS to be split with his partner. They will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. He will use his loan share to buy and sell fish to more customers. He dreams of buying a car and building another house.

loans.use: to increase his stock of fish to meet customer demand.

loans.name: Ma. Luisa

texts.en:
As a married mother of three children, Ma. Luisa works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns income from pig fattening and rice retailing. Ma. Luisa is borrowing PHP 20000 through NWTF to purchase more goods like snack food, canned goods, noodles and other groceries to resell.

Ma. Luisa has sustained her business because of 21 previous loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. 

She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to expand her business and send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase feed, medicine and vaccines for her pigs.

loans.name: Eliud

texts.en:
Hello lenders, meet Eliud. Eliud is an industrious farmer living in Simai village, found in the North Rift area of Kenya. 

On Eliud's farm, dairy and crops are products. His main income sources are from selling milk and maize. 

Eliud is seeking a loan from Kiva lenders to pay for farm inputs. Maize is a seasonal crop that requires heavy investment early on and brings rewards at the end of the season. 

Eliud could use income from milk to bankroll these operations but not without neglecting the needs of his family. A loan will enable Eliud to pay for crop cultivation costs without denting his family's living standards. 

A fraction of income from milk sales will enable him to make initial repayments on his loan.

loans.use: to pay for farm inputs.

loans.name: Saima

texts.en:
Saima is a 45-year-old woman who lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. She is a responsible mother of six sons. Her husband is a rickshaw driver by profession. For the past many days his rickshaw has not been working properly, thus impacting his ability to generate income.

Her husband wants to repair it as soon as possible. However, due to the lack of money, he finds it difficult to cover the cost of repairs. Therefore, Saima has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan to help her husband to cover the cost of repairing rickshaw.

loans.use: to pay for rickshaw repairs.
